abstract.p: We present a new algorithm to compute the classical modular polynomial Φ l in the rings Z[X, Y] and (Z/mZ)[X, Y], for a prime l and any positive integer m. Our approach uses the graph of l-isogenies to efficiently compute Φ l mod p for many primes p of a suitable form, and then applies the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT). Under the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH), we achieve an expected running time of O(l 3 (logl) 3 log logl), and compute Φ l mod m using O(l 2 (logl) 2 + l 2 log m) space. We have used the new algorithm to compute Φ l with l over 5000, and Φ l mod m with l over 20000. We also consider several modular functions g for which ${\mathrm{\Phi }}_{\mathrm{l}}^{\mathrm{g}}$ is smaller than Φ l , allowing us to handle l over 60000.
